text: LaRON GREEN, the witness, being first duly sworn, testified under oath as follows: EXAMINATION
Can you do me a favor and state your name for the record?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: My name is LaRon Green.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: LaRon?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: LaRon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did I misspell it?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: It's L-a capital R-o-n, Green like the color.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What we're doing today is taking your deposition, and by that I mean we have a court reporter who has sworn you in, and she's going to take down on her machine every word you say and every word I say, all right?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in order to make it easy for her, I'll try not speaking when you're speaking if you'll try not speaking when I'm speaking.  That way she doesn't have to do two conversations at once.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Confirmed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And also, nodding your head -- which everyone does -- yes or no, that means she's got to interpret what we're doing, so if we just articulate yes or no as opposed to nodding the head.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Confirmed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The other thing is what I'm trying to do is get a record here that when I ask you a question, I get an answer, I want to make sure that the answer is -- you were answering my question.  So basically if I ask you a stupid question or one that doesn't make sense to you, just tell me that; we'll get a new question.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So I've asked you to come here today because you've been identified as a witness by Victor Franklin to what he says was an injury, okay?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Mr. Franklin said that he was at a bar with you and a gentleman named Michael Franklin and a gentleman from Africa.  He didn't know the name of him.  Do you recall -- and this would have happened in 2013.  Do you recall being at a bar with those three other gentlemen?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: That sounds -- like I said before, it's been several years, and thinking of this after you guys contacted me, I can only recall it being my cousin Mikey Franklin from LA and his cousin who I thought was of African descent, or I knew it was somebody that had some vague accident. Now, you're saying that there was a third person that was there.  Oh man, like I said, my recollection of this is very fuzzy --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: -- very fuzzy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let me ask you this:  Do you know Victor Franklin?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.  I know my cousin Mikey Franklin.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So when you say you don't -- let's just kind of work it this way:  Victor Franklin, you say you don't know him?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Can I explain the situation?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: My cousin Mikey Franklin, he lives in LA, and I see him rarely, maybe once every three or four years.  And this trip he said, "Hey, cuz, let's hang out and meet up."  He called me, and I said, "Okay, I have a client that's playing down at the Czar Bar, and we can go, kill two birds with one stone.  I can go support my client, listen to them play music, and we can visit at the same time." He said, "Fine." I picked him up.  I picked Michael Franklin up in my vehicle, and he said that his cousin was going to meet us down there; so we pulled up to the Czar Bar, and I remember a gentleman of, I believe, indigenous African descent whom I thought to this point was his cousin, showed up.  And I could be totally mistaken on the fourth person.  I just don't have a clear memory of that, but now that you guys say that, it's a definite possibility.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's put it this way:  Do you feel comfortable that Mikey Franklin and an indigenous African person were there?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: There, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And if there was a fourth person, you're not clear about that?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I'm not 100 percent clear about that, but now that you guys say that, that could have been the case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: My cousin Mikey Franklin in LA would be the universal person would know who would have known everybody that was there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said you had a client, and for the record, if the jury wants to know, you're a hair stylist?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I am a hair stylist.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So your client would be someone whose hair you style their hair for?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this client, do you recall their name?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the name?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Her name is Vicky Harris.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Vicky Harris?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And she was the musician or is the musician?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.  Her husband is a musician, and he was playing down at the Czar Bar.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the husband, do you know the husband's name?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is his name?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Charlie Harris.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was he a solo performer?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.  He was playing with a few other gentlemen, two other gentlemen maybe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Were they playing when you were there?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: They were playing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What time did you get there?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't know the time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you got there, was the band already playing?  I say "band," Charlie Harris and two other gentlemen?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I believe so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What sort of music were they playing?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Jazz infusion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is their instruments they were playing?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Well, I know Charlie plays the bass guitar.  The other gentlemen, I'm not for sure of their instruments.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so have you ever been to this bar before?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell me where it's located?  Do you recall where it's located?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Vaguely.  Main Street downtown.  I guess it would be in the area of around 15th and Main would be my guess.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you describe the bar?  Was it in a standalone building or --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.  It was inside of a -- it was not in a standalone building that I can recall.  It was in a storefront.  It appeared to kind have been a shotgun setup, a straight front-to-back setup.  The stage area where the musicians were performing were at the four opposite ends of the establishment, and where we were sitting was very close to the front door.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And "we" would be?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Mikey Franklin and the other gentleman.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And maybe a fourth person?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Maybe a fourth person.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How long -- did you stay there for the entire performance?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't remember exactly how long I was there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you leave with Mikey, or did you leave by yourself?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yeah, I left with Mikey Franklin.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And the performance may have been ended; it may still have been still going on?  You don't recall?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't recall.  I recall them maybe finishing up a set when we walked in, and then through the intermission, I went over to the front area, greeted them, and then went back to the seating area.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, if they were a -- you say a shotgun.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: They were at the far end.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The far end and you were at the front of the bar?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Right, yeah, the opposite.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was there any people in between the bandstand and where you were sitting?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: There were seats in the sitting area in between.  I don't know who or how many people were sitting in between us.  I can guess and say maybe a handful, less than 10 people.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: But I'm not for sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And they were sitting at booths and tables?  Do you recall what they were --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I believe it would be cabaret style from my recollection of the layout.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what would that be?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: That would be table top with maybe three to four chairs surrounding.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you notice anything about the chairs they were sitting in?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you notice anything about -- were you sitting in a chair, or were you sitting in a booth?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I was sitting in a chair.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall anything about that chair?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So at some point you and Mikey Franklin got up and left.  How about the indigenous African?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't know exactly.  We all probably left around the same time since we all commonly were there visiting my cousin Mikey Franklin.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the indigenous person didn't come with you, but he may have left with you?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.  Well, he did not come with us.  He showed up at the same -- we all walked through the front door together.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you left, for sure Mikey Franklin left with you because you drove --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I was his ride.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then when you left, did you give him a ride somewhere else?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: If I did, I don't remember exactly where we went afterwards.  Maybe dropped him off over at his family's house.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall where you went ultimately that night?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No, I don't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So you have a rough estimate of how long you may have been at the bar that night?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: A rough estimate would be an hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And is Charlie Harris still -- is he still in Kansas City?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how to get ahold of him?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I can attempt to get ahold of him.  I don't know for sure, but I can make an attempt to get ahold of him.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about Vicky Harris, the same thing?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes, I can make an attempt.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So while you were there, you have never -- was there a name for this band?  Do you recall that?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Chilliott.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Chilliott?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't know how to spell it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Chilliott?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And then infusion jazz being what? How do you define "infusion jazz"?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Kind of a modern jazz.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Not discordic or dysphonic.  It's more of a smooth jazz?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I would say on the smooth -- I don't know how to describe it, I'm sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  But a three-person group?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: From my recollection, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And during the time you were there, were you guys having any drinks or anything?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I may have had a beer.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you recall if anyone else drank?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No, I don't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the period of time you were there, you first got there and you went up front and said hi to your -- to Charlie Harris --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: What happened, when we first got there -- and I'm not 100 percent clear on the timeline of events -- but when we first got there, we sat down up front, the band was playing at that time.  I mean we sat down in the back of the room because the band was playing at that time, and from my recollection five minutes after we got there is when the -- I do remember a chair collapsing when we first got there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Um-hum.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: It was early on when we got there the chair collapsed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Tell me about that.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: We were just sitting there talking.  We hadn't ordered any drinks yet.  We had just sat down, and the chair, I believe, collapsed, within like the first five minutes of us being there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What chair collapsed?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: It would have been to the left of me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who was sitting in that chair?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I believe it was Victor -- Mikey Franklin's cousin.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I thought you didn't know if there was a third or a fourth person there?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I was recollecting -- I was under the influence that the gentleman who may have been indigenous African, because of his accent, was Mikey's cousin; but like I said, this has been six years ago plus to me.  It was not an event that I'm very clear on; so let me be clear with that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I appreciate that.  This lawsuit was just filed, you know, last year; so we're trying to find some facts now. So let's go back.  You recall a chair collapsing?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You recall a person who was in that chair when it collapsed?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know who that person --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: That person was a cousin of my cousin Mikey Franklin.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Can you describe him?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.  I could not pick him out of a lineup, nor the indigenous African person, I wouldn't be able to pick him out of a lineup either.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say the chair collapsed, did you see it collapse?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you see?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I seen someone sitting next to me, and the next thing you know they are on the floor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you get up and do anything?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I didn't think anything of it when it happened, you know.  It -- if my chair would have collapsed, I would have just got back up and got in the next chair.  No problem at all.  It wasn't a great distance of a fall, and he seemed to be an able-bodied young man.  So it's not like it was an elderly woman who fell.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say the chair collapsed, did you examine the chair?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So did you see the chair itself collapse, or did you see a person go to the ground?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I saw a person go to the ground.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see anyone examine the chair?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No, not that I'm aware of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you talk to anyone while you were there about this person that was on the ground?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And you didn't examine the chair?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see anyone examine the chair?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Not that I paid any attention to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see anyone remove the chair?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I'm sure someone came from the bar area and I believe brung over another chair and possibly, most likely, removed that chair.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  When you say "most likely," you're assuming that happened or do you recall that happening?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Well, I'm recalling us continuing to sit there and enjoy the evening and not being encumbered by a broken chair in our way.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You keep saying "broken chair." You did not observe the chair to be broken; you just observed a person falling to the ground?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I observed the person falling to the ground.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I did not physically go over and inspect the chair, but I'm pretty sure that that chair was broken.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: How it broke?  I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say "pretty sure it was broken" that's based upon --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I'm sorry to interrupt, but I'm assuming that that chair was inoperable from that point forward from the manner of it disappeared out of my vision --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: -- to where you were not able to see a chair anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But I guess -- because all this ends up being something that people want to hear -- what happened to cause the gentleman to go to the ground is based upon you assume happened, not based upon your examining the chair to see if it actually collapsed or not; is that true?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Could you please rephrase that for me?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  A person that was sitting in the chair fell to the ground.  You made an assumption that the chair collapsed which caused him to fall to the ground; is that true?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes, that assumption is true because I did not see him making any awkward motions or leaning forward or back in the chair.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And after he fell to the ground, you didn't examine the chair nor look at the chair to determine if the chair, in fact, had fallen or had broken?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I did not lift up and physically examine the chair, but from the state that the chair was no longer in my site of vision, the chair most likely was damaged beyond anyone else sitting back in the chair.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's because the table was on the ground?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But you didn't see it on the ground?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: The chair?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: He was sitting next to me.  I'm sure I looked at the chair and seen it out of my field of vision.  As to how it broke or why it broke, honestly, I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I understand.  And again, you're assuming it broke.  I guess that's what I'm trying to get to. I want to make sure that -- if you say it broke, I want to know how it broke, what you saw, all of that stuff; and if you don't recall any of this, then that's where we are.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct, I don't recall how it broke or what condition the chair was in after the incident happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  All you can say, in fact, a person fell to the ground, and your assumption is the chair broke which caused him to fall to the ground?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This person was sitting right next to you?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So the chair -- someone moved the chair, removed that chair, and another chair was brought up for this gentleman to sit in?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this gentleman -- you're comfortable this gentleman is a cousin of Mikey Franklin, but you don't recall his name?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After this happened, was there any other incidences?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have a conversation with this person who was sitting in the chair about what happened?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Not that I can recollect.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall him indicating he had been hurt or felt like he hurt or acting like he had been hurt?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Not -- no, not that I can recall.  We continued to enjoy the rest of the evening.  If someone in my party was hurt, we would have immediately sought medical help for it, you know --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: -- for that person.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you say for "the rest of the evening," you know, did you stay until Chilliott completed their performance for the evening?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't know how long their performance was.  I know there was an intermission to where I got a chance to go up front and say hello to the entertainers and listen to them play maybe a few more songs.  I don't know if that was the end of their set or if we just left at that time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And the cousin of Mikey Franklin, did you take him home that night?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't remember taking him home.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, I called you, I guess, last week or maybe the week before that to ask you if there was a date we could do this deposition --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- and then after that, I spoke to you, I think, on Friday just to remind you, and then today you called to get a good address?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than that, have you and I had any conversations about this case?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you had any conversations with Mikey Franklin about this case?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Not this year.  He called me maybe two -- maybe two or three years ago and said that some attorney may be calling me about a deposition or calling me asking questions about the case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: And I told him at the time, "I don't remember much."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone call you?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Someone -- a woman did call.  She asked me questions over the phone.  What those questions were at this point, I don't know.  What law firm she was representing, I don't know, but I believe she would have possibly been the attorneys for his cousin Victor Franklin, I believe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you recall, was this conversation recorded?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No that I know of.  I remember that I was on my cell phone about to go inside of a grocery store; so it was a short conversation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So your cousin called you two or three years ago and said, "An attorney may be calling you."  You got a phone call from an attorney, female attorney, and you had a brief call on the cell phone?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yeah, I'm assuming she was an attorney.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is that about it?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you had any other conversations about this case?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: None that I can think of now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Was there a cover charge that night; do you recall?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall any of the people that were working there or appeared to be working there?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you had any conversations with -- have you gone to Charlie Harris' performance since then?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No, I have not been to a Chilliott performance since then.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know if they're still a group?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't think so.  He probably still does music, but I don't think they still have a group because the other gentlemen that were in the group were not from Kansas City.  They're from other cities, other states.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When this person fell, was the band playing at that time?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I believe so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there a lot of noise when that happened?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Not to where it would have stopped the music or if they would have noticed it up front.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So basically, a person went to the ground, chairs were placed --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Life went on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Life went on. Okay.  All right.  So let me just -- I have your address as -- not Belton.  It's Peculiar, right?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.  You have my address as 404 East Gregory Boulevard, Kansas City, Missouri.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's your work address, right?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  That's all the questions I have for now.  This gentleman may have a few.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Okay. EXAMINATION
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Green, do you remember who worked at the bar saying anything to Victor after he fell?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: I don't remember any conversation, no. I'm not saying that there was not a conversation, but I can't recall any conversation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anybody that worked at the bar say anything to Mikey at the time that Victor fell?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: Possibly there was probably -- with Mikey being a comedian, I'm sure he was cracking jokes; so if so, he may have made a wisecrack to a staff member.  What?  I don't remember or wouldn't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember, was the staff people that came and replaced the chair, do you remember what they looked like?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No.  Caucasian male but I can't recall -- I wouldn't be able to pick them out of a lineup.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This Caucasian male didn't say anything to you, correct?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember if that Caucasian male provided the group any sort of benefit because the chair fell at the table, meaning, like, "Here's free drinks"; "Cover charge is free tonight"?  Anything like that?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: I'm not sure.  I don't recall.  I don't -- I wouldn't know.  I wouldn't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you talk to Victor later on in the evening about the chair falling?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: Not that I remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you say anything to Mikey about the chair falling later on in the evening?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: Again, because he's a comedian, I'm sure he made a quip about it, and maybe we chuckled, laughed, or bantered, but no in-depth conversation about the chair falling that I can recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any knowledge about what injuries Victor may have suffered as a result of this fall?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you talked to any of Victor's doctors or health care providers about what injuries he suffered as a result of this fall?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you spoken to anybody that works for the Czar Bar about Victor's injuries as a result of this fall?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you talked to anybody at the Czar Bar about whether the chair was safe or not?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you talked to anybody at the Czar Bar about whether they knew the chair was unsafe or not?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you talked to anybody else other than Mikey and the female attorney about this case?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No, I have not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Excuse me, you also spoken to Mr. Hufft about this case, but those three people -- the female attorney, Mr. Hufft, and Mikey -- are those the only three people you have talked to about this case?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: In detail, yes.  I mentioned to my wife that I had a deposition today and it's regarding something that happened several years ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But other than that, you haven't spoke to anybody else about the specifics of the case?
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: No, I have not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I don't think I have any other questions. Thank you, Mr. Green. REEXAMINATION
speaker: MR. BOSLER

text: I just want to make sure.  The location of the bar that you went to that night, you and Mikey and this indigenous African went to, you said it was 15th and Main or thereabouts?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: That's the general recollection that I would be able to surmise, but I don't know the exact address at all.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember -- and I asked you this and I meant to follow-up again -- it was not a standalone building?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: It was a storefront.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say "a storefront," more than one --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: More than one retail opportunity.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you recall where in this storefront the bar was located?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Lower level, ground -- street level.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Was there any other establishments to either side of it, or was it the only one at that lower level?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you been there since then?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you been -- I mean, have you ever gone back and looked at this place --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This place that you say is the Czar Bar, where do you get that name?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I believe from the name being on the front of the establishment, and then it's a pretty unique name, and I'm sure other people have referenced the Czar Bar as a popular hangout.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So you saw the name Czar Bar on the front when you were there?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I believe I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And has anyone else told you that's where you were that night?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I don't think anybody told me that's where I was.  I think maybe that's where they said they were playing at that night.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So Charlie Harris would have told you, "That's where we're playing"?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: If my memory serves my correctly, yes, but I'm not 100 percent sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I think that's all the questions I have.  Now, let me tell you the next part of this game.  The court reporter is going to type up the deposition.  It will be in a little booklet form like this (indicating).  You've got a couple of choices.  Let me go through them so she knows what she needs to do.  So she can mail this to you.  And then you then have an option:  You can read it. There will be a page at the back for -- like this (indicating) --
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- where you can make -- if you think there's something that's been taken down correctly, you can put your changes there, and then also there's a place to sign and say that you agree with the contents, okay?
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Or you can waive that.  You can assume she's going to take it down correctly.  So it's your choice what you want to do.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Okay.  Do I have to make a choice now?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sorry.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: I assume that she's going to do a good job taking notes; so no further action on my behalf is required.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you. Electronic versions again like we did before?
speaker: THE REPORTER

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. HUFFT

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. BOSLER
